results.title: Choice for Year Nine
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changes…From the Inside”.
Devised by Glenn and Les Mack for the Supplementary Grants Program of Victoria and records how the staff of a regional technical school respond to the attitude problems of Year 9 students.

results.title: Red Tape
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changes…From the Inside”.
Devised by Glenn and Les Mack for the Supplementary Grants Program and shows a school community breaking down barriers to encourage community involvement in school decision making. The school draws its pupils from a housing commission estate and the principal’s aim is to create a school that responds to the community rather than the conventional process of making the commnity respond to the bureaucratic needs of the school.

results.title: Why Not the Kids?
results.creator_credit: Chelsea Productions and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changes…From the Inside”.
Devised by Glenn and Les Mack for the Supplementary Grants Program of Victoria and shows how children can participate in school organisation. Children at a Victorian Primary School formed a committee and applied for and were granted a Supplementary Grant. The children suggested changes in school facilities, organisation and even curricula. In doing so, some of changes that occured challenged teachers’ perceptions of students and caused them to reappraise their role in the school community.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chelsea Productions and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development

results.title: Closing the Gap
results.creator_credit: Glenn Mack, Les Mack and Chelsea Studios for the Education Department of Victoria
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changes…From the Inside”.
Devised by Glenn and Les Mack for the Supplementary Grants Program of Victoria. Raises issues of concern for those attempting to bridge the gap between schools and the local community. Depicts the first tentative steps of a small inner-city secondary school.
Filmed at the historic, heritage registered building on City Road, Southbank, formerly the J.H. Boyd Girls’ High School, now (2017) known as the ‘Boyd Community Hub’.

results.title: Artisans of Australia
results.creator_credit: Paul Humfress, Pamela Paddon and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A four part tape that features master stonemason George Proudmen, moulder Jack Thomas, stained glass artist Kevin Little and axemen Bill Boyd and Mark Gardner at work during conservation and restoration work on National Estate places such as Coolamine Homestead, Garrison Holy Trinity Church and the Sydney Technical College at Ultimo.

results.title: Don't think I don't think. Fair enough
results.creator_credit: Dale Baker, Open Channel Productions, La Trobe University, Preston Institute of Technology and Hodja Ed Res Co-op
results.brief_description: 1. “Don’t think I don’t think”. A workshop of the 1981 South Pacific Regional Conference on Mental Retardation. 2. “Fair enough”. The experiences of students finding difficulty in mantaining dignity and rights in the face of “hidden curricula” of school.

results.title: Seeds of change
results.creator_credit: Diane O'Connor and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Examines changes in Victorian farm life documenting its evolution from horse to tractor to modern machinery. Filmed on location at Jeparit, this program uses period re-creation and documentary footage.

results.title: Not only to save our jobs
results.brief_description: Shows how a group of people at a small Melbourne manufacturing company acted to overcome the threat of losing their jobs by setting up a new form of organisation based on worker participation in ownership and decision-making. The effects on employees’ attitudes and work relationships are shown.
results.description: Shows how a group of people at a small Melbourne manufacturing company acted to overcome the threat of losing their jobs by setting up a new form of organisation based on worker participation in ownership and decision-making. results.title: You Can Do It Too!
results.creator_credit: Diane O'Connor and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: A character called “x”, who is neither male nor female, points out all the opportunities available to people when gender is made irrelevant. Shows how role stereotyping begins at birth and carries through into school and work. Shows men and women working and finding fulfilment in non-traditional areas. The band playing towards the end of the film features the now ABC political journalist, Fran Kelly, in an unfamiliar guise.

results.title: Energy Conservation in the Home
results.creator_credit: Dept of Minerals and Energy AV Workshop
results.brief_description:
“Energy conservation in the home” provides useful information on the ways in which energy can be saved within the household.

See also Related Title 325491 “Victoria’s energy”; uses stills to analyse Victoria’s energy position during 1980-81.
